title: Revealing Mass Transport Mechanisms and Pathways across Materials Using Isotopic Tracers and Atom Probe Tomography
content: With its combination of high-spatial resolution, 3D imaging, and isotopic sensitivity, atom probe tomography (APT) provides a unique platform with which to study solid-state transport phenomena and mechanisms. In this presentation, I will discuss recent technique developments for combining isotopic tracers and APT, and its application to iron-based metals and oxides, which are of broad scientific and applied significance ranging from geochemistry to catalysis to nuclear environments. Whether considering the autocatalytic reactivity of surfaces during mineral recrystallization [1, 2], self-diffusion within bulk metals or oxides with embedded isotope tracers [3], or diverse oxygen transport pathways existing across metal-oxide heterostructures [4], APT is a powerful technique for capturing subtle atomic transport phenomena with unprecedented detail. Further, utilization of in situ atom probe capabilities enables high controllability of reactions at localized regions of interest, thereby enabling clear observation and quantification of self-diffusion (Fig. 1). Through these examples and experiences, I will also discuss challenges associated with this approach as well as potential new research opportunities [5].
